title-group.article-title: Potential Mechanism for the Laser-Fluoride Effect on Enamel Demineralization

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering, 9 Engineering Drive, National University of Singapore
2Faculty of Dentistry, National University of Singapore, 11 Lower Kent Ridge Road, Singapore 119083
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, National University of Singapore
4Division Bioengineering, School of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering, 70 Nanyang Drive, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 637457

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2013 International & American Associations for Dental Research
permissions.copyright-holder: International & American Associations for Dental Research

abstract.p: Laser-induced prevention of dental caries has been studied extensively. However, the cariostatic mechanisms of a combined fluoride-laser treatment are not well-understood. Using micro- computed tomography (micro-CT), we quantified the effect of fluoride and/or Er:YAG laser treatment on enamel demineralization. The mean mineral loss (%/V) for each group was 4,870 ± 1,434 (fluoride followed by laser treatment), 6,341 ± 2,204 (laser treatment), 7,669 ± 2,255 (fluoride treatment), and 10,779 ± 2,936 (control). The preventive effect of the laser (p < 0.001) and fluoride (p = 0.010) treatment was statistically significant. Characterized by micro-x-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, the significant contraction in the a-axis after both laser and combined laser/fluoride treatment was revealed (both p < 0.05). In conclusion, subablative low-energy Er:YAG laser irradiation following fluoride treatment may instantaneously transform enamel hydroxyapatite into fluoridated hydroxyapatite to reduce enamel solubility as a preventive treatment for enamel demineralization.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fluoride has been proven to be an effective treatment for the prevention of dental caries by inhibiting demineralization and enhancing remineralization (Wefel, 1990) and by reducing the metabolic activity of bacteria (Pandit et al., 2011). Additionally, lasers have been shown to inhibit enamel demineralization (Fried et al., 1996) and reduce enamel permeability (Maung et al., 2007a). Studies have demonstrated that a combined fluoride-laser treatment makes enamel more resistant to acid than does either laser treatment or fluoride treatment alone (Flaitz et al., 1995; Hsu et al., 2001). A significant increase in fluoride uptake on the enamel surface and enamel crystallinity has been demonstrated (Goodman and Kaufman, 1977). To study the crystallographic properties of irradiated and/or fluoridated enamel, investigators have previously used powder x-ray diffraction (XRD) (Goodman and Kaufman, 1977; Okazaki et al., 1981). However, site-specific crystalline information pertinent to the mechanistic investigation may be lost in destructive sample preparation. To provide unbiased data, micro-XRD may be more suitable because of its non-invasive sample preparation (Al-Jawad et al., 2007).

As part of a series of studies to elucidate the mechanisms of the combined fluoride-laser effect on human enamel, the purposes of the present study were to: (1) verify whether subablative Er:YAG laser irradiation could provide a significantly greater inhibition of enamel demineralization compared with that provided by fluoride treatment alone; (2) quantify crystallographic changes in enamel treated with fluoride (F), laser (L), and combined fluoride-laser (FL) therapies; and (3) consolidate potential mechanisms involved in the cariostatic effect of the combined laser-fluoride (LF) treatment. The specific hypothesis of this study is that subablative low-energy Er:YAG laser irradiation following fluoride treatment can instantaneously transform enamel hydroxyapatite into fluoridated hydroxyapatite and reduce enamel solubility.

sec.title: Tooth Selection and Grouping
sec.p: Ten human non-carious premolars, stored in 0.1% thymol solution, were obtained following the approval of the Institutional Review Board (NUS-IRB reference code: 04-106E). The teeth were cleaned and covered with nail varnish, with 4 windows (1×1 mm) left on each tooth, randomly assigned to the control (C), laser (L), fluoride (F), or fluoride-laser (FL) treatment group.

Five sound human premolars were selected for characterization by x-ray diffractometry (XRD). Three windows (1×1 mm) were created on the buccal surface of each tooth. The areas inside the windows were carefully assessed by stereomicroscopy to ensure that no pre-existing carious or defective structures were present.

sec.title: Fluoride Treatment
sec.p: The F and FL groups were treated with topical fluoride Nupro NeutralTM (Johnson and Johnson, Inc., New Brunswick, NJ, USA), containing 2.0% NaF (9,047 ppm) for 4 min. All fluoride gel on the tooth surface was wiped off with wet tissue paper. After the FL group received immediate laser treatment, the F and FL groups were rinsed in the same container for 10 min.

sec.title: Laser Treatment
sec.p: The L and FL groups were subjected to laser irradiation with an Er:YAG laser (Fotona Fidelis®, Ljubljana, Slovenia) at the following operating conditions: VSP (very short pulse, 100 μsec) mode, 100 mJ, 5 Hz and 5 sec, with 5.1 J/cm2, 0.5 mm spot, and a 10% attenuator (Dielectric mirror, Einst, Singapore) without water and air supply. The C and L groups were subsequently rinsed with de-ionized water for 10 min.

sec.title: Stereomicroscopy Characterization
sec.p: Potential morphological changes in all of the windows were characterized by stereomicroscopy at a magnification of 25× (SZ4045TR, Olympus®, Tokyo, Japan) before and after laser/fluoride treatment and pH cycling.

sec.title: Crystallographic Assessments
sec.p: Before and after the aforementioned F/laser treatments, crystallographic analysis was performed on the windows by XRD with a micro-x-ray diffractometer system (D8 Gadds Hi-star Area Detector, Bruker, The Helios, Singapore). Cu-Kα radiation was generated at a tube voltage of 40 kV with a beam spot 500 µm in diameter and a 0.005-degree step size. The values of the a-axis and c-axis were calculated according to Bragg’s equation, 2dsinθ = λ, from the (300) and (002) reflections, respectively.

sec.title: pH-cycling Process
sec.p: A four-day pH-cycling scheme was performed, with 22-hour demineralization, followed by 2-hour remineralization at 37ºC and a 130-rpm stir rate (Damato et al., 1988). The demineralization solution at pH 4.5 contained 0.05 M acetic acid, 2.2 mM calcium, and 2.2 mM phosphate ions. The remineralization solution at pH 7.0 contained 0.15 M potassium chloride, 1.5 mM calcium, and 0.9 mM phosphate ions. A 10-minute wash in de-ionized and distilled water was performed between the demineralization and remineralization phases and at the end of the process. Both demineralization and remineralization solutions were changed daily.

sec.title: Micro-computed Tomography (micro-CT) Scanning
sec.p: Each window was imaged after pH-cycling with a Shimadzu SMX-100CT (Shimadzu, Tokyo, Japan) micro-CT scanner. A cone-CT imaging acquisition technique was used to capture several hundred CT images in one acquisition. The micro-CT x-ray source was set at 38 kV and 107 mA, providing 7.230 mm of in-plane (XY) field of view and an isotropic resolution of 7.06 µm. To evaluate the most representative mineral profile, we scanned the center of each window (Fig. 1).

caption.p: Illustration of control and experimental windows. C, control; L, laser; F, fluoride; FL, fluoride/laser; # intact region; I, II, the scanning plane.

sec.title: Quantification of Demineralization
sec.p: Images were analyzed with the X-ray Image Viewer (Media Cybernetics Inc., Rockville, MD, USA). A rectangular box (80 µm wide) was plotted on a representative zone of each window, with the top of the box overlapping the natural surface. The average gray-level profile within the 80-µm-wide box was obtained as a function of distance from the natural surface. The same threshold was used for all images, to eliminate the edge effects. Gray values were converted to mineral content (g/cm3), on the assumption that the component absorbing the x-ray was calcium hydroxyapatite (Efeoglu et al., 2005). A hydroxyapatite disk (Plasma Biotal Ltd., Buxton, UK) with a density of 2.8 g/cm3 was scanned with the same scanning parameters.

To prevent individual and/or site-specific variation in the mineral density among samples, we used as controls the gray-value intensities of the intact regions between the experimental windows to calculate the percentage of mineral loss for each group.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Regarding the data of mineral loss, a factorial analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used for simultaneous assessment of the effects of both laser and fluoride treatments in preventing enamel demineralization and their potential statistical interaction. Thereafter, the paired t test with appropriate Bonferroni corrections was applied for assessment of the pair-wise comparison of 4 groups and between the baseline and post-treatment crystallographic data. Because the crystallographic data among the treatment groups were not normally distributed, the non-parametric Kruskal-Wallis test, followed by the Mann-Whitney test and proper Bonferroni adjustments, was used. The differences were considered significant when p < 0.05.

sec.title: Qualitative Assessment
sec.p: No observable morphological changes were identified by stereomicroscopy after the laser or fluoride treatments. During the pH cycling, the enamel surfaces of the 4 groups gradually became dull, indicating increased mineral loss over time. All 4 groups increased in whiteness at the end of pH cycling. Approximately 20% of the lased spots in the L group and 60% of those in the FL group showed a semitransparent color after a four-day acid challenge. Compared with the other groups, the control group presented the deepest lesion depth under micro-CT (Fig. 2).

caption.p: Representative (a) micro-CT images and (b) correlated mineral profiles of C (control), L (laser), F (fluoride), and FL (fluoride and laser).

sec.title: Quantitative Assessment of Mineral Loss
sec.p: The mean mineral losses for the FL, L, F, and C groups were 4,870 (1,434), 6,341 (2,204), 7,669 (2,255), and 10,779 (2,936) %/V, respectively (Table 1). A significant preventive effect was found for both the laser (p < 0.001) and fluoride treatments (p = 0.010), but not for their statistical interaction (p = 0.193). The laser treatment alone provided 41.2% prevention of enamel demineralization, whereas the combined laser-F treatment was 54.8%, significantly better than 28.9%, which was obtained by fluoride treatment alone (p = 0.042).

caption.p: Effects of Fluoride and/or Laser Treatments on Mineral Loss

fn.label: a
fn.p: Data were obtained from one-way ANOVA with p < 0.001, after the equality of variance was confirmed with the Levene test (p = 0.364).

fn.label: b
fn.p: The ranking order was obtained from post hoc Tukey tests. Groups with different numerals were statistically significantly different at a level of p < 0.05. The p values of pairwise comparisons between L and C, F and C, FL and C, FL and F are 0.001, 0.024, < 0.001, and 0.042, respectively.

sec.title: XRD Result
sec.p: No new phase was detected in the diffraction pattern of any sample, nor was there any change in the c-axis. The a-axis parameters for the untreated samples ranged from 9.451 to 9.473 Å, decreased 0.004 (p = 0.001) and 0.011 Å (p < 0.001), respectively, after the F and the FL treatments (Table 2).

caption.p: Lattice Parameters of Untreated and Treated Samples

fn.label: a
fn.p: The difference between baseline and post-laser treatment for the L group in the a-axis dimension is p = 0.001.

fn.label: b
fn.p: The difference between baseline and post-laser treatment for the FL group in the a-axis dimension is p < 0.001.

fn.label: c
fn.p: The overall difference was obtained from the Kruskal-Wallis test with p = 0.002. Statistical significance was as follows: between F and L with p = 0.015, L and FL with p = 0.027, and F and FL with p = 0.015. The pairwise comparisons were obtained from the Mann-Whitney test with Bonferroni adjustment to obtain the ranking order.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Based on the data obtained in this study and those published previously, there may be 4 primary mechanisms involved in the cariostatic effect of low-energy laser-fluoride treatment on enamel demineralization.

sec.title: Purification of Enamel Hydroxyapatite (HAP)
sec.p: One of the main mechanisms may be the laser-induced formation of a less-soluble enamel structure caused by decreased carbonate and crystalline water, increased structural OH, and the potential formation of pyrophosphate (Holcomb and Young, 1980; Fowler and Kuroda, 1986). It has been suggested that the temperature rise from the Er:YAG laser with a laser energy density of 5 J/cm2 may reach 230°C (Fried et al., 1996). The compositional changes of enamel heated in the range of 100 ~ 200°C include the reduction of water content (%) by 12% ~ 27% (Holcomb and Young, 1980) and a decrease in CO32− content by 13% ~ 23% (Deng, 2003). These compositional changes in enamel resulted in purer hydroxyapatite crystalline structures and may explain, at least partially, the observed 0.004 Å contraction of the a-axis and the 41% reduction in enamel demineralization. Increased acid resistance of enamel that was heated from room temperature to 400°C has also been reported (Sato, 1983), with a 0.013 Å contraction of a-axis parameters in this temperature range (Sakae, 1988). Based on the nearly linear association between the temperature rise and the contraction of the a-axis (Sakae, 1988), the estimated laser-induced temperature increase to approximately 250°C in this study may be plausible and thus substantiates the laser-induced purification of the human enamel structure as a major cariostatic mechanism.

sec.title: Reduction of Enamel Diffusion
sec.p: The photothermal effect of a low-energy laser treatment may also cause a reduction in enamel permeability (Stern et al., 1966; Yamamoto and Sato, 1980; Hsu et al., 2000). The pore volume and surface area of the lased enamel powder decreased significantly, by 16.7% and 11.9%, respectively (Ying et al., 2004), particularly the pores with diameters under 50 Å. A set of laser parameters similar to those used in this study demonstrated a 36 to 62% reduction in enamel diffusion (Maung et al., 2007a). However, the effectiveness of laser treatment significantly decreased by 34 to 75% after partial removal of organic matter (Maung et al., 2007b). High-energy laser treatment may potentially burn away the organic matrix above 400°C (Holcomb and Young, 1980). Therefore, the diffusion-inhibiting effect of a laser treatment on enamel demineralization might be preserved by the use of lower energy laser therapy such as that used in the present study.

sec.title: Increased Fluoride Deposition on Enamel Surfaces
sec.p: As demonstrated in previous studies, fluoride uptake on the enamel surface increased from 579.3 ppm to 932.21 ppm after argon laser treatment (Nammour et al., 2003) and by 37% more than the control after CO2 laser irradiation (Hsu et al., 2004). The fluoride deposited on the enamel surface, most likely in a form similar to CaF2, did not change the crystalline structure in this study (Table 2) and may be released from the surface during acid attack to reduce demineralization and enhance remineralization (Tenuta et al., 2008).

sec.title: Formation of Fluoridated Hydroxyapatite
sec.p: In addition to the aforementioned mechanisms, CO2 laser treatment may transform synthetic hydroxyapatite into “fluorapatite” in the presence of fluoride (Meurman et al., 1997). The apatitic fluoride concentration in the enamel may reach 400% of the original concentration after CO2 laser irradiation (Hsu et al., 2004). In comparison with the lattice parameters of the L group, those of the LF group showed an additional contraction (0.007 Å) in the a-axis, which is likely due to the laser-induced incorporation of fluoride into the lattice structure. It has been reported that the parameters of the a-axis in human enamel change linearly with fluoridation concentration (nF/nAP) in the apatitic lattice, with an approximately 0.07 Å reduction in the a-axis per unit of nF/nAP fluoridated crystalline structure (Larsen and Jensen, 1989). Therefore, laser-induced nF/nAP in our study was estimated to be approximately 0.1 units. Based on the linear relationship between nF/nAP and enamel solubility (Larsen and Jensen, 1989), the estimated reduction in enamel solubility in the present study may fall in the range of 10 to 20% and is substantiated by the additional 13.6% reduction of enamel demineralization in the FL group in comparison with that of the F group (Table 2).

In summary, based on the data from the present study and those in the literature, low-energy Er:YAG laser irradiation coupled with fluoride treatment may inhibit enamel demineralization through photothermal purification of enamel HAP, inhibition of enamel diffusion, increased fluoride deposition on the enamel surface, and formation of fluoridated hydroxyapatite.

sec.title: Bio-safety Issues
sec.p: Although laser-induced micro-cracks on enamel surfaces have been reported in a few studies utilizing “subablative laser treatment” (Apel et al., 2002, 2005), this study used laser therapy with an even lower energy density, repetition rate (Hz), and shorter duration than those used by Apel et al. Therefore, the laser-induced temperature rise on enamel surface could be lower, and subsequent damage-free enamel surfaces could be made possible in this study. In addition to laser parameters, the site-specific tooth structure may play a critical role in determining the exact temperature rise on the enamel surface, since slight variations in water content may lead to different laser-tissue interactions (Apel et al., 2002). Although the laser parameters chosen in this study fell into the ‘safe’ range, further studies may be needed for direct measurement of the instantaneous temperature rise on enamel surfaces and in the pulp, so that clinical applications of laser treatment can be made possible and ethically acceptable.

The subablative low-energy Er:YAG laser irradiation following fluoride treatment may instantaneously transform enamel hydroxyapatite into fluoridated hydroxyapatite and thus increase the acid resistance of enamel.

fn.p: A supplemental appendix to this article is published electronically only at http://jdr.sagepub.com/supplemental.

The authors declare no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
